title: Chapter 1 How deep the machine learning can be11footnote 1Submitted to appear in book ”A closer look at deep learning”, by Nova

sections.the moon-shot of linear performance scal:
Despite the early warnings [ref]5 [ref]8 the computing followed the path dictated by the Moore’s Law:
the moon-shot of unlimited growing of computer performance, not considering that the growth seems to be exponential only at the beginning  and
”a trend that can’t go on ad infinitum.”.
The development efforts concentrated on achieving high-performance single-processor, but
there are scientific reasons why the ’single-processor’ computation shall reach a limit [ref]11 .
Another moon-shot today is parallelization, the only way to
increase the computing performance of the system with conventional processors is to parallelize the sequentially working processors.
Even today an (exponentially) linear dependence is expected  and the ”gold rush” for
achieving exascale performance  is going on.
Even in the most prestigious journals  . However, as demonstrated decades ago, the computing performance not only does not increase linearly with the number of computing units, but also decreases after exceeding a critical number of processors [ref]8. Although the EFlops (payload) performance has not yet been achieved, already the 104superscript10410^{4} times higher supercomputer
performance is planned .
It looks like that in the feasibility studies an analysis,
whether an inherent performance bound exists, remained out of sight in USA   or in EU 
or in Japan  or in China .
However, at extreme large scale systems serious performance limitations occur  . The parallelized sequential processing has different rules of game [ref]8, : the performance gain (”the speedup”) has its inherent bounds . It has recently been admitted that it ”can be seen in our current situation where the historical ten-year cadence between the attainment of megaflops, teraflops, and petaflops has not been the case for exaflops”.
